metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: The multi-scale observation experiment on evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces  (MUSOEXE-12)-Dataset of flux observation matrix (No.4 eddy covariance system) from May to Sep, 2012
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from site No.4 eddy covariance system (EC) in the flux observation matrix from 31 May to 17 September, 2012. The site (100.35753° E, 38.87752° N) was located in a residential area in Yingke irrigation district, which is near Zhangye, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1561.87 m. The EC was installed at a height of 4.2 m (6.2 m after 19 August); the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (CSAT3&Li7500A) was 0.17 m.
Raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Edire post-processing software (University of Edinburgh, http://www.geos.ed.ac.uk/abs/research/micromet/EdiRe/), including spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. Moreover, the observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC), which was proposed by Foken and Wichura [1996]: class 1 (level 0: Δst<30 and ITC<30), class 2 (level 1: Δst<100 and ITC<100), and class 3 (level 2: Δst>100 and ITC>100), representing high-, medium-, and low-quality data, respectively. In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 3% of the 30 min raw record; and (4) data were rejected at night when the friction velocity (u*) was less than 0.1 m/s. There were 48 records per day; the missing data were replaced with -6999. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m^3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m^3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (z/L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m^2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m^2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m^2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xlsx format.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2016) (for multi-scale observation experiment or sites information), Xu et al. (2013) (for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Concept Completion.Answer: outlier removal, time delay correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, density correction, quality evaluation of flux values

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used in capturing eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface?
Example.Answer: One example of a data collection method used in capturing eco-hydrological processes involves the use of a flux observation matrix, which includes eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations. This approach is part of the HiWATER project, which aims to observe multiscale eco-hydrological processes.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when collecting multiscale observations in eco-hydrological research?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge in collecting multiscale observations in eco-hydrological research is the poor availability of such observations, which hinders progress in understanding the processes on heterogeneous surfaces. The HiWATER experiment addressed this challenge by utilizing hierarchically nested scales to obtain comprehensive data.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset that illustrates the use of remote sensing in eco-hydrological studies?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset illustrating the use of remote sensing in eco-hydrological studies is from the HiWATER project, which includes hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing data collected using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer. This dataset captures the eco-hydrological processes over an oasis-desert area.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the detailed procedures involved in processing raw eddy covariance data to ensure quality and accuracy?
Feature Specification.Answer: removal of outlier values, correction for time delays, coordinate rotation, frequency response corrections, sonic virtual temperature correction, density (WPL) corrections, quality evaluation, data filtering

Feature Specification.Answer: soil and canopy component temperatures, air temperature, wind speed, humidity, four-component radiations, turbulent fluxes

Comparison.Question: How do the data processing techniques used in the flux observation matrix dataset compare to those used for the multiscale dataset obtained during the HiWATER experiment?
Comparison.Answer: The flux observation matrix dataset utilizes Edire software for a series of processing steps including outlier removal, delay time correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, and density corrections. Quality evaluation is based on atmospheric stability and turbulent similarity characteristics. In contrast, the multiscale dataset from HiWATER includes a wide range of data sources such as eddy covariance towers and remote sensing, and focuses on multi-scale observations. The data processing involves calibration, data collection, and generation, ensuring careful quality control across different data types.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data collection frequency and temporal resolution between the eddy covariance system used in the flux observation matrix and the instruments used in the HiWATER experiment?
Comparison.Answer: In the flux observation matrix, the eddy covariance system records data at a high frequency of 10 Hz, which is then aggregated to provide 30-minute averages. For the HiWATER experiment, the data collection includes various temporal resolutions: meteorological parameters are measured every 10 minutes, and thermal images are taken every 120 minutes during daytime hours, showcasing a broader range of data collection frequencies tailored to different instruments and measurements.

Comparison.Question: How do the challenges of measuring evapotranspiration using the TSEB model compare to those encountered in collecting multiscale observations in the HiWATER experiment?
Comparison.Answer: The TSEB model faces challenges such as effectively separating soil and canopy temperatures and dealing with uncertainties in advective environments, particularly in arid regions. These are compounded by errors in image classification and temperature estimation. The HiWATER experiment, on the other hand, is challenged by the poor availability of multiscale observations, necessitating a comprehensive observation system with multiple nested scales to capture eco-hydrological processes. Both endeavors highlight difficulties in accurate data acquisition and measurement under complex environmental conditions.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges in data quality control can be inferred from the need for extensive sensor calibration and the integration of diverse data sources in a multiscale observation system?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of diverse data sources and the need for extensive sensor calibration suggest challenges in maintaining data consistency and accuracy across different scales and instruments. These challenges may include sensor drift, variations in sensor precision, and discrepancies in spatial and temporal resolution, which require rigorous quality control protocols throughout the data collection and processing phases to ensure reliable and interpretable datasets.

Interpretation.Question: What methodological considerations are necessary when using thermal infrared imaging to separate soil and canopy temperatures for evapotranspiration estimation in heterogeneous landscapes?
Interpretation.Answer: Methodological considerations include accurately classifying soil and canopy pixels using image classification techniques, correcting for atmospheric and surface radiation transmittance, and validating component temperatures with ground-based measurements. These steps are crucial to minimizing errors due to image classification inaccuracies and ensuring the reliability of evapotranspiration estimates in heterogeneous landscapes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in accurately estimating surface fluxes in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Accurately estimating surface fluxes in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas is challenging due to the incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy, uncertainties in surface-air temperature differences, and errors in determining component temperatures from composite radiometric temperatures. Additionally, the strong advective environment further complicates the estimation process.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is multiscale observation considered a challenge in the field of eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenge in multiscale observation for eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces arises from the poor availability of multiscale data. This limitation hinders progress in understanding and modeling these processes accurately, necessitating experiments like HiWATER designed to capture data at multiple scales and across various disciplines.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the reasons for errors in the derived component temperatures when using image classification methods in arid regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Errors in the derived component temperatures in arid regions are primarily caused by image classification errors, which vary with vegetation abundance. Misclassification of soil and vegetation pixels can lead to overestimation of canopy temperatures. Additionally, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance, as well as errors in estimating incoming radiation transmittances, can introduce further uncertainties.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using a multiscale observation experiment for data collection in heterogeneous land surfaces?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a multiscale observation experiment addresses the challenge of upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces, as it provides multiscale and multidisciplinary data through the use of a flux observation matrix, eco-hydrological sensor networks, and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the intent behind integrating multiple observation scales in the data collection method for eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intent is to address the challenge of upscaling eco-hydrological processes by utilizing a hierarchically nested instrumentation setup that captures multiscale and multidisciplinary data, enhancing the understanding of these processes in complex environments.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in processing eddy covariance data for quality control and ensuring accurate flux measurements?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The eddy covariance data is processed using Edire software, which includes steps like outlier removal, time delay correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, and density correction (WPL). Quality evaluation is performed on flux values, checking for atmospheric stability and turbulence characteristics. Data is filtered for instrument errors, precipitation impact, and missing data thresholds to ensure accuracy.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are employed to accurately separate soil and canopy component temperatures for evapotranspiration estimation in a strongly advective environment?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Soil and canopy component temperatures are separated using high-resolution thermal cameras to capture thermal radiation. The visible and NIR images are classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method, and their brightness temperatures are extracted from thermal images. These temperatures are converted to radiation temperatures using incoming long-wave radiation data and emissivities, allowing for accurate estimation of component temperatures.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the effective separation of soil and canopy component temperatures in strongly advective agricultural areas?
Enablement.Answer: The separation of soil and canopy component temperatures can be effectively enabled by using ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures, high-resolution thermal cameras, and the series TSEB model, which leverages thermal images to accurately calculate component temperatures. This approach, validated against observed E/ET% and T/ET% using stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, provides reliable estimates even under strongly advective conditions.

Enablement.Question: What factors contribute to the successful application of the TSEB model in estimating evapotranspiration over heterogeneous landscapes?
Enablement.Answer: The successful application of the TSEB model in estimating evapotranspiration is contributed by factors such as accurate measurements of soil and canopy component temperatures using thermal cameras, reliable validation against EC system measurements, and the ability to separate latent fluxes of soil and vegetation components. The model's effectiveness is also enhanced by addressing uncertainties in surface-air temperature differences and providing separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% ratios.

Expectation.Question: What challenges could arise in estimating surface fluxes using the Two-Source Energy Balance (TSEB) model in strongly advective regions, and how can they be addressed?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges in estimating surface fluxes using the TSEB model in strongly advective regions include the model's sensitivity to surface-air temperature differences and uncertainties caused by errors in determining component temperatures. Addressing these challenges involves using accurate ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures and validating model outputs with techniques like stable isotope analysis and eddy covariance measurements.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the primary challenges in using thermal infrared cameras for estimating soil and canopy component temperatures in agricultural regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Using thermal infrared cameras to estimate soil and canopy temperatures poses challenges such as classification errors in image processing, which can lead to overestimation of canopy temperatures. Additionally, atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance errors can contribute to uncertainties in temperature estimation, especially in regions with varying vegetation abundance.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how data from multiple observation scales can be integrated effectively to study eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous landscapes.

This involved a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations, along with hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes.

Assertion.Answer: Accurate processing of eddy covariance data, especially in strongly advective regions, involves addressing the energy balance closure issue by considering factors such as the uncertainty in surface-air temperature differences. The TSEB model accounts for these uncertainties by using soil and canopy component temperatures, validated against observed data, to provide reliable estimates of energy fluxes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe how the eddy covariance technique is utilized for data collection in heterogeneous landscape evapotranspiration studies.
Request/Directive.Answer: The eddy covariance technique is employed to measure turbulent fluxes, such as heat and moisture, in heterogeneous landscapes by using a setup involving an eddy covariance system. This system samples data at high frequencies (e.g., 10 Hz) to capture the rapid fluctuations in wind speed, temperature, and gas concentrations. This data is then processed to obtain 30-minute flux averages, after conducting corrections for coordinate rotation, frequency response, and density adjustments. Such a method is crucial for accurate evapotranspiration estimation over complex surfaces, as demonstrated in the Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline how the HiWATER experiment addresses multi-scale observation challenges in eco-hydrological research.
Request/Directive.Answer: The HiWATER experiment addresses multi-scale observation challenges by implementing a hierarchically nested observation system that includes flux observation matrices, eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations. This setup is complemented by an eco-hydrological sensor network for soil moisture and leaf area index measurements. Additionally, hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and microwave radiometers provides comprehensive data coverage. This approach facilitates the capture of multi-scale eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert regions, ensuring robust data collection across varied spatial and temporal scales.
